Renata Bravo y dura situación que vivió con su hija en toque de queda: "No se le va a olvidar nunca"
La actriz confesó que lo pasó horrible.
03 Nov 2019 by Yem Manríquez
La actriz Renata Bravo relató en Podemos hablar de CHV una particular situación que vivió con su hija, por la que fueron obligadas a salir en toque de queda.
"Lo pasé horrible. Tuve un problema, mi hija se enfermó. Pensé que era apendicitis y tuve que salir con toque de queda y llevarla a la clínica. Yo creo que el recuerdo que vivió ella esa noche no se le va a olvidar nunca", contó.
"Me pararon 4 veces los militares (armados) de mi casa a la clínica", detalló. Pero la situación se complicó también por vecinos de Camino El Alba en Las Condes: "Como éramos el único auto en la calle la gente pensaba que veníamos a atacar sus casas, y nos apuntaban (con escopeta) directo al auto".
"Todo eso lo vio mi hija de 9 años, y ella no vivió la dictadura, pero ese recuerdo no se le va a olvidar nunca de su mente", sotuvo la actriz.
"Hay gente que sufrió demasiado con el toque de queda y no debió haber sabido lo que significaba, porque no lo merecíamos creo yo", afirmó, concluyendo que la crisis social era una cosa se podía haber "solucionado antes" de su estallido.

Renata Bravo and hard situation that lived with her daughter in curfew: "You will never forget"
The actress confessed that she had a horrible time.
03 Nov 2019 by Yem Manríquez
The actress Renata Bravo related in We can talk about CHV a particular situation she lived with her daughter, for which they were forced to leave in curfew.
"I had a horrible time. I had a problem, my daughter got sick. I thought it was appendicitis and I had to go out with a curfew and take her to the clinic. I think that the memory she lived that night will never be forgotten." he counted.
"The military (armed) from my house stopped at my clinic 4 times," he said. But the situation was also complicated by residents of Camino El Alba in Las Condes: "As we were the only car on the street people thought we were coming to attack their houses, and they pointed us (with a shotgun) directly at the car."
"All that was seen by my 9-year-old daughter, and she did not live the dictatorship, but that memory will never be forgotten from her mind," said the actress.
"There are people who suffered too much with the curfew and should not have known what it meant, because we did not deserve it," he said, concluding that the social crisis was one thing that could have been "solved before" of its outbreak.
